item.title: How Elixir and Erlang handle recursion?
item.author: marcogbarcellos@gmail.com (Marco Gabriel Barcellos)
item.description: A tail call function is a function which call another functions as its last thing: def first_func(...) do ... another_func(...) end In most Object Oriented languages, whenever you start calling functions recursively, they are all pushed to the stack. In Elixir and Erlang, we have what’s called tail-call optimization. This optimization works in a way that’s similar to a goto or a jump and you don’t need allocate more memory when pushing more functions to the stack.
